The Central African ambassador in Washington, D. C. is the official representative of the Government in Bangui to the Government of the United States.

|
|Michel Gallin-Douathe
|GALLIN-DOUATHE, MICHEL. Born, Limassa, Central African Republic, 4 June 1920. Education, l'Ecole Na- tionale de France d 'outre- Me r (Paris). Was counselor for administrative affairs in charge of French technical assistance in the Central African Republic and also was adviser to the government of French Equatorial Africa in Brazzaville. Also appointed Ambassador to the United States in addition. 15 November 1960 Permanent Representative to the UN. On November 4, Central African Republic Representative Michel Gallin-Douathe was refused service at a diner near Baltimore, Maryland, while returning to New York City from Washington, where he had just presented his credentials. 1963: Ambassador Michel Gallin-Douathe, Central African Republic's permanent delegate to the United Nations, declared here that the government of the Republic of China is the only lawful government that can represent the Chinese people.
|David Dacko
|Dwight D. Eisenhower

*minister of foreign affairs.
*1989: Permanent representative United Nations, New York City.
